## How Chat List Renderer Manages Streaming Response Parts

The VS Code chat list renderer uses a sophisticated **progressive rendering system** to smoothly display streaming responses as they arrive. Here's how it works:

### 1. **Progressive Rendering Loop**

When a response is actively streaming (incomplete), VS Code sets up a timer-based progressive rendering loop:

```typescript
// From renderChatTreeItem method
if (isResponseVM(element) && index === this.delegate.getListLength() - 1 && (!element.isComplete || element.renderData)) {
    const timer = templateData.elementDisposables.add(new dom.WindowIntervalTimer());
    const runProgressiveRender = (initial?: boolean) => {
        if (this.doNextProgressiveRender(element, index, templateData, !!initial)) {
            timer.cancel(); // Stop when complete
        }
    };
    timer.cancelAndSet(runProgressiveRender, 50, dom.getWindow(templateData.rowContainer)); // 50ms intervals
    runProgressiveRender(true);
}
```

### 2. **Word-Based Rate Control**

The renderer controls how fast content appears using a word-based rate system:

```typescript
private getProgressiveRenderRate(element: IChatResponseViewModel): number {
    const rate = element.contentUpdateTimings?.impliedWordLoadRate;
    if (element.isComplete) {
        return clamp(rate, 80, 2000); // Faster when complete
    }
    return clamp(rate, 5, 2000); // Slower during streaming
}
```

The system calculates how many words to render based on:
- **Time elapsed** since last render
- **Target rendering rate** (words per second)
- **Current word count** already rendered

### 3. **Content Chunking and Word Counting**

Text content is broken into words using a sophisticated regex that handles:
- Markdown links
- Inline math
- Chinese characters
- Code-like content (
AI: )

```typescript
private getNextProgressiveRenderContent(element): { content: IChatRendererContent[], moreContentAvailable: boolean } {
    let numNeededWords = data.numWordsToRender;
    
    for (const part of renderableResponse) {
        if (part.kind === 'markdownContent') {
            const wordCountResult = getNWords(part.content.value, numNeededWords);
            if (wordCountResult.isFullString) {
                partsToRender.push(part); // Render full chunk
            } else {
                // Render partial chunk with trimmed text
                partsToRender.push({ 
                    ...part, 
                    content: new MarkdownString(wordCountResult.value) 
                });
                moreContentAvailable = true;
            }
        }
    }
}
```

### 4. **Efficient Diff-Based Rendering**

Instead of re-rendering everything, the system uses a **diff algorithm** to identify what changed:

```typescript
private diff(renderedParts, contentToRender, element): Array<IChatRendererContent | null> {
    const diff = [];
    for (let i = 0; i < contentToRender.length; i++) {
        const content = contentToRender[i];
        const renderedPart = renderedParts[i];
        
        if (!renderedPart || !renderedPart.hasSameContent(content, contentToRender.slice(i + 1), element)) {
            diff.push(content); // Needs rendering
        } else {
            diff.push(null); // No change
        }
    }
    return diff;
}
```

### 5. **Smart DOM Updates**

The 
AI:  method efficiently updates the DOM:

```typescript
private renderChatContentDiff(partsToRender, contentForThisTurn, element, elementIndex, templateData) {
    partsToRender.forEach((partToRender, contentIndex) => {
        if (!partToRender) return; // null = no change
        
        const alreadyRenderedPart = templateData.renderedParts?.[contentIndex];
        
        // Special handling for thinking parts - update in place
        if (partToRender.kind === 'thinking' && alreadyRenderedPart instanceof ChatThinkingContentPart) {
            alreadyRenderedPart.updateThinking(partToRender);
            return;
        }
        
        // Dispose old part and create new one
        alreadyRenderedPart?.dispose();
        const newPart = this.renderChatContentPart(partToRender, templateData, context);
        
        if (newPart) {
            // Smart DOM replacement
            if (alreadyRenderedPart?.domNode) {
                alreadyRenderedPart.domNode.replaceWith(newPart.domNode);
            } else {
                templateData.value.appendChild(newPart.domNode);
            }
        }
    });
}
```

### 6. **Content Part Management**

The system manages different types of content parts:

- **References**: Always rendered first to avoid content shifting
- **Markdown content**: Progressive word-by-word rendering
- **Tool invocations**: Rendered as complete units
- **Thinking parts**: Special in-place updates during streaming
- **Working indicators**: Shown when appropriate

### 7. **Height Management**

The renderer carefully tracks and updates item heights:

```typescript
updateItemHeightOnRender(element: ChatTreeItem, templateData: IChatListItemTemplate) {
    const newHeight = templateData.rowContainer.offsetHeight;
    element.currentRenderedHeight = newHeight;
    
    // Use animation frame to handle async content like code blocks
    const disposable = dom.scheduleAtNextAnimationFrame(() => {
        element.currentRenderedHeight = templateData.rowContainer.offsetHeight;
        this._onDidChangeItemHeight.fire({ element, height: element.currentRenderedHeight });
    });
}
```

### Key Benefits of This Approach:

1. **Smooth streaming effect**: Text appears gradually rather than in chunks
2. **Performance**: Only renders what changed using diffs
3. **Responsive**: Maintains UI responsiveness during streaming
4. **Adaptive**: Rendering rate adapts to content arrival speed
5. **Memory efficient**: Properly disposes old content parts
6. **Flexible**: Handles different content types (text, code, tools, thinking)

This system creates the smooth, typewriter-like effect you see when AI responses stream in VS Code's chat interface.

title: Copilot context-aware of recent file changes and edits
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
Hello,

I’d like to suggest a feature for Copilot in VS Code:  
Please add a context option for Copilot to be aware of my recent file changes and edits across the workspace, not just the currently open or selected file. This would help Copilot give more accurate and helpful responses based on my development context and current functionality I'm trying to implement, especially when changes span multiple files. This would greatly reduce time of managing contexts manually and keep workspace clean of open file tabs.

Ideally, Copilot would have access to my last N edits or a configurable history of file changes, which it could use to inform its suggestions and answers in Copilot chat.

Thank you for considering this feature.

title: Add default chat mode setting with dynamic configuration support
body:
This PR implements a new user setting `chat.defaultMode` that allows users to configure their preferred default chat mode for new chat sessions. The setting supports both built-in modes (Ask, Edit, Agent) and custom modes defined in `.chatmode.md` files.

## Key Features

**Dynamic Configuration**: The setting automatically updates its available options when chat modes change. When custom modes are discovered or removed, the dropdown options refresh in real-time without requiring a restart.

**Smart Initialization Logic**: Chat sessions now follow a priority chain when determining the initial mode:
1. State-provided mode (when restoring saved state)
2. **Configured default mode** (new setting)
3. Persisted last mode (previous behavior)
4. Ask mode (fallback)

**Robust Validation**: If a configured default mode becomes unavailable (e.g., custom mode file deleted), the system logs a warning and gracefully falls back to the next option in the priority chain.

## Implementation Details

- **`DynamicChatModeConfiguration`**: New service that listens to `IChatModeService.onDidChangeChatModes` events and dynamically updates the configuration schema with available modes
- **Enhanced `ChatInputPart.initForNewChatModel()`**: Modified initialization logic to check the configured default mode first, with proper validation
- **Configuration constant**: Added `ChatConfiguration.DefaultChatMode = 'chat.defaultMode'` for consistent reference

## User Experience

The setting appears in VS Code's Chat settings with a dropdown showing:
- Built-in modes with descriptive labels (e.g., "Ask - Ask questions and get general assistance")
- Custom modes with their names and file paths
- Real-time updates when new custom modes are discovered

## Testing

Added comprehensive unit tests covering:
- Dynamic configuration updates when modes change
- Initialization logic with various scenarios
- Validation and fallback behavior
- Mock services for reliable testing

This change maintains full backward compatibility while providing users with a convenient way to set their preferred default chat mode.

title: add a "variables" section to launch.json

labels.name: *duplicate
labels.description: Issue identified as a duplicate of another issue(s)

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
when developing complex projects with lots of unit tests and scripts and methods of launching, the launch.json file can get quite large, with dozens of configurations. if you share this file with your dev mates, they must modify all the paths of every configuration.

it would be amazing to have a variables section at the top of the launch.json file that could be updated for each engineer, or when switching worktrees or changing dev environment, and then all your configurations would inherit the updated variables and you would not need to change every config separately, on every different machine, with possibly different drive letters or names, different usernames, different paths to dev environments ets.

eg:
    "variables": {
        "rootContainer": "/Users/davec/src",
        "mainPath": "${rootContainer}/main",
        "sparePath": "${rootContainer}/spare",

	"defaultPath": "${mainPath}",      <--- this makes it easy to switch worktrees
		
	"aeDirPath": "${defaultPath}/AfterEffects",
	"pproDirPath": "${defaultPath}/PremierePro",
	"buildPath": "${defaultPath}/build",
	"buildAppPath": "${buildPath}/mb/xcode_macos_arm64/Debug/arm64/build",
	"aeAppPath": "${buildAppPath}/AfterEffects/AfterEffects/AfterEffects/After Effects (Beta).app",
	"pproAppDirPath": "${buildAppPath}/PremierePro/PremierePro/PremierePro",
    },

then your config could use eg:${aeAppPath}, and it would "just work" even if one of the cascading vars changed.

title: Implement validateToolsObject function for prompt syntax validation
body:
This PR implements the missing `validateToolsObject` function in the prompt validator to support validation of tools specified as a hierarchical object/map structure, in addition to the existing array format.

## Problem

The `validateToolsObject` function was left empty, causing no validation for tools specified in the object format shown in the test case "prompt file tools as map". This meant users could specify invalid tool configurations without receiving proper validation feedback.

## Solution

Implemented comprehensive validation for the tools object structure that supports:

### Top-level Categories
- `built-in`: Can be a boolean (e.g., `built-in: true`) to enable all built-in tools
- `mcp`: Object containing MCP server configurations  
- `extensions`: Object containing extension tool configurations

### Example Structure
```yaml
tools:
  built-in: true
  mcp:
    vscode-playwright-mcp:
      browser-click: true
  extensions:
    github.vscode-pull-request-github:
      openPullRequest: true
      copilotCodingAgent: false
```

### Validation Features
- **Category validation**: Ensures only valid top-level categories are used
- **Recursive validation**: Validates nested tool specifications within categories
- **Tool name validation**: Checks that tool names exist in available tools
- **Type validation**: Ensures tool values are booleans or nested objects
- **Clear error messages**: Provides localized error messages for different validation failures

## Changes Made

1. **Core Implementation**: Added the `validateToolsObject` method with recursive validation logic
2. **Error Handling**: Added localized error messages for invalid categories, unknown tools, and incorrect value types  
3. **Test Coverage**: Added 6 comprehensive test cases covering various validation scenarios
4. **Backward Compatibility**: Updated existing error message to reflect support for both arrays and objects

## Testing

The implementation includes extensive test coverage for:
- Valid object structures with mixed known/unknown tools
- Invalid top-level categories  
- Incorrect value types for categories and tools
- Real-world examples matching the parser test structure

All tests validate the expected error messages and severity levels (warnings for unknown tools, errors for structural issues).

title: mcp: fix image preview for links and add momentary cache
body:
- Fix tool results with resource-link's not showing image thumbnails
- Add a 'CancellationTokenPool' for memoization of cancellable operations
- Add a 'momentaryCache' to McpResourceFilesystem to avoid multiple reads
  in quick succession (since now we read the image to show the thumbnail
  in addition to two reads we were already doing)

title: remove setting
Add Ctrl+click to collapse all comment threads in editor from Comments view
body:
Implements the ability to Ctrl+click on comments in the Comments view to open the file at the comment location and collapse all comment threads in that editor, providing a quick way to navigate to code while minimizing visual clutter from expanded comments.

## Changes

This PR adds new functionality to the Comments view tree interaction:

- **Regular click** (existing behavior): Opens file and expands/reveals the specific comment thread
- **Ctrl+click** (new behavior): Opens file and collapses ALL comment threads in that editor

## Implementation Details

The implementation enhances the existing `onDidOpen` event handler in `CommentsView` to:

1. **Detect Ctrl+click events** by checking `browserEvent.ctrlKey` 
2. **Pass collapse intent** to the `openFile` method via a new optional parameter
3. **Collapse comments after opening** by getting the active editor's `CommentController` and calling `collapseAll()`
4. **Handle diff editors** by selecting the appropriate side (modified or original)
5. **Use timing safeguards** with a 100ms timeout to ensure the editor is fully loaded

## Usage Example

When working with multiple comment threads in a file:
1. Open the Comments view (View → Comments)  
2. **Regular click** on any comment → file opens with that comment expanded
3. **Ctrl+click** on any comment → file opens with all comments collapsed

This is particularly useful when reviewing code with many comment threads, allowing developers to quickly navigate to specific locations while keeping the editor view clean and focused.

## Testing

- Added unit test to verify both regular click and Ctrl+click behavior
- Passes CodeQL security analysis
- Maintains full backward compatibility with existing functionality
- Handles edge cases (no active editor, diff editors, missing controllers)

title: Add Ctrl+click to collapse all comment threads in Comments view
body:
Fixes #266727

This PR adds support for **Ctrl+click** functionality in the Comments view that collapses all comment threads in the editor, similar to the existing Ctrl+click behavior for code folding.

## Problem

Users requested the ability to quickly collapse all comment threads in an editor when clicking on comments in the Comments view panel. Currently, clicking on a comment always expands and reveals that specific comment thread.

## Solution

Added detection for the Ctrl modifier key when clicking on comments in the Comments view:

- **Normal click**: Opens file and reveals/expands the specific comment thread (existing behavior preserved)
- **Ctrl+click**: Opens file and collapses ALL comment threads in that editor (new behavior)

## Implementation Details

The implementation leverages VS Code's existing comment infrastructure:

1. **Event Detection**: Modified the `onDidOpen` event handler in `commentsView.ts` to detect Ctrl key press from the browser event
2. **Parameter Flow**: Added optional `ctrlPressed` parameter to the `openFile` method  
3. **Function Enhancement**: Updated `revealCommentThread` function with optional `collapseAll` parameter
4. **Action Logic**: When Ctrl+click is detected, calls the existing `CommentController.collapseAll()` method instead of revealing the specific thread

## Example Usage

When working with multiple comment threads in a file:

1. **Regular workflow**: Click any comment in Comments view → file opens and that comment expands
2. **New Ctrl+click workflow**: Ctrl+click any comment in Comments view → file opens and ALL comments collapse

This provides consistency with VS Code's existing Ctrl+click behavior for collapsing code sections and gives users a quick way to get an uncluttered view of their code while still navigating to the relevant file.

## Testing

- ✅ Backward compatibility maintained - all existing comment functionality works unchanged
- ✅ Security analysis passed with no vulnerabilities detected
- ✅ Implementation follows VS Code architectural patterns
- ✅ Minimal code changes focused on the specific feature request

title: [MacOS 26 Tahoe] High GPU usage by WindowServer on Intel-based MacBook Pro (2019, 16-inch) when running VSCode
body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No - VS Code Version: 1.104.0 (Universal) - OS Version: macOS 26 (Tahoe) - Device: MacBook Pro 16-inch, 2019 (Intel chip) - GPU: AMD Radeon Pro AMD Radeon Pro 5300M Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open VSCode on Intel-based MacBook Pro (2019). 2. Observe system performance via Activity Monitor. 3. Notice that the `WindowServer` process shows unusually high GPU usage (around 90%). Expected Behavior: VSCode should run smoothly without causing excessive GPU usage on Intel-based MacBooks. Actual Behavior: - `WindowServer` process consistently shows high GPU usage (up to ~90%) when VSCode is running. - System performance becomes noticeably slower. - This issue is not obviously observed on Apple Silicon (M-series) devices.

title: Revert "Remove redundant activation & log extension service activation errors…"
body:
This reverts commit ea1973f76886eea5140ab831f96d84762217bf85.

This commit accidentally changed activation from Immediate to Normal in some situations and Normal doesn't seem to activate until after a resolver resolves.

Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/266319

title: Adds padding for chat disclaimer welcome message when it has no chat history
body: I notice that in recent versions of copilot/ vscode, the chat padding for the disclaimer welcome message seems to have no padding. This pr fixes that spacing issue by using the same padding used for when the chat has history.

title: Checkout: 'Place Order' button is unresponsive on Safari browser

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
- Steps to Reproduce:
  1. Log in to an account on the Safari browser (v16.5+).
  2. Add at least one item to the shopping cart.
  3. Proceed to the checkout page and fill in all required shipping and payment details.
  4. Click the final 'Place Order' button.
- Expected Result: The order is processed, and the user is redirected to the order confirmation page.
- Actual Result: The 'Place Order' button shows a loading spinner indefinitely, but the order is never processed. The browser's developer console shows a `TypeError: null is not an object`.
- Environment:
  - Browser: Safari 16.5 on macOS Ventura
  - Device: MacBook Pro M1
  - User Impact: Critical - Prevents Mac users from completing purchases.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VBA file
2.  apply the following prompt
```
              You are editing a VBA module. Follow these strict rules:
              
              1. **Allowed edits:**
                 - Add, update, or remove *comment lines only*.
                 - A comment line in VBA starts with an apostrophe `'` or with the keyword `Rem` (case-insensitive), optionally preceded by whitespace.
                 - You may insert new comment-only lines above routines or at the top of the file.
              
              2. **Forbidden edits:**
                 - Do NOT modify, move, or delete any code lines (anything that is not a comment).
                 - Do NOT change whitespace, indentation, MsgBox strings, function signatures, or variable names.
                 - Do NOT reformat code.
                 - Do NOT add example code snippets; if you want to show examples, put them in comments.
              
              3. **Commenting style:**
                 - Add a standard module header at the very top with:
                   ' Author: Mustafa Isleyen
                   ' Version: 1.17.7
                   ' Change log is managed externally
                 - Add full header blocks (as comments) above every `Public ...` routine.
                 - Use English for all comments, even if variables or MsgBox text remain in Dutch.
                 - Clarify and improve debug flag explanations (comments only).
                 - For API calls, add per-endpoint purpose + sample response *shape* (in comments).
                 - Add high-level sequence diagrams in comments for workflows (RunKostenbewakingsoverzichtWithPrompt / Refresh / Rollover).
                 - Remove obsolete comments that merely restate the code.
                 - Normalize variable commentary to English.
                 - Add performance notes (comments only) where caches are built.
                 - Add WARNING markers (comments only) where sheet structure assumptions exist.
              
              4. **Scope:**
                 - Entire module.
              
              5. **Output:**
                 - Show the diff where ONLY comment lines (`'...` or `Rem ...`) are changed.
                 - If a requested change would require altering code, respond with: "NO-OP: would change code."
```

Issue:
Beside adding and editing comments, large blocks of code is removed.

title: Shell integration leaks variables

labels.name: debt
labels.description: Code quality issues

labels.name: terminal-shell-integration
labels.description: Shell integration infrastructure, command decorations, etc.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes
<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: Version: 1.104.0

- OS Version: macOS Sequoia Version 15.6.1 (24G90)

These variables defined by the shell integration logic leak and interfere with other scripts:

- bash_major_version
- envVarsToReport
- use_associative_array
- vsc_env_keys
- vsc_env_values

They should either not leak after usage (e.g. `unset`), or at least be consistently namespace-partitioned.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. echo the variables above

Steps to Reproduce:

I am a developer building an extension based on the Webview provided by VS Code.
In my extension, I create a Webview and render the UI on it using React.

The problem is that starting from version 1.104, the Content Security Policy (CSP) is not being applied correctly.

As shown in the screenshot below, even though I have added CSP-related settings to the <head> of the HTML used in the Webview, 

<!-- Failed to upload "image.png" -->

the Webview Developer Tools console continues to throw CSP-related errors like below. 

<!-- Failed to upload "image.png" -->

The key issue is that with the same app and the same scenario, this problem does not occur in versions prior to 1.104.

Could you let me know if there are any additional steps we need to take on our side regarding this? Or is this a bug in the latest version? A quick response would be greatly appreciated.

title: High GPU Usage by WindowServer When Opening Projects in VS Code After macOS 26 Update

labels.name: upstream
labels.description: Issue identified as 'upstream' component related (exists outside of VS Code)

labels.name: freeze-slow-crash-leak
labels.description: VS Code crashing, performance, freeze and memory leak issues

labels.name: macos
labels.description: Issues with VS Code on MAC/OS X

labels.name: electron
labels.description: Issues and items related to Electron

labels.name: upstream-issue-linked
labels.description: This is an upstream issue that has been reported upstream

labels.name: unreleased
labels.description: Patch has not yet been released in VS Code Insiders

body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes - VS Code Version: 1.104.0 (Universal) - OS Version: macos 26 Darwin arm64 25.0.0 Steps to Reproduce: After updating to macOS 26, I encountered a significant GPU usage spike whenever I open a project in VS Code. The issue is specifically tied to the WindowServer process, as observed in Activity Monitor. Here are the key observations: 1. When VS Code is open without any project loaded, GPU usage remains normal. 2.The GPU usage returns to normal levels when VS Code is displayed in full-screen mode. This behavior suggests a potential rendering or compositing issue related to windowed mode when projects are active. Could the team please investigate this compatibility problem between VS Code and macOS 26?

title: Provide auto working directory option for `New Terminal`
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
In the workspace working mode, there are multiple repos in Explorer.
`Source Control Provider` will auto switch to current active repo. But `New Terminal` not.
When you click `New Terminal` button, manual selection is always required. But click `Source Control Provider`, it has "Auto" option.

And also if Terminal has never been created in the panel, terminal will auto created with the current directory. 
If you want more terminals, manual selection is required. 
When there are many repos(> 10) in an editor, it is not easy to operate.

I hope `New Terminal` has similar functions as `Source Control Provider`.

Append: Not sure if it's a config issue or a bug. At `TERMINAL` panel, 
If click "New Terminal   Ctrl+Shift+\`"  and  "New Terminal Window  Ctrl+Shift+Alt+\`" at `V` button‘s Drop-down menu. 
Terminal will auto created with the current directory. 

But click `+` button or press `Ctrl+Shift+\`` shortcut key, will require manual select work directory.

And after create a new window by "New Terminal Window  Ctrl+Shift+Alt+\`". The new window's `+` button always auto create with the current active directory(This is also the behavior I expect).

But the old window's `+` button still need manual select work directory.

title: Feature Request: Increase VS Code UI corner radius on macOS 26 “Tahoe” to match system roundness
body:
## Summary
macOS 26 (“Tahoe”) increased default window/control corner radii. VS Code still uses tighter radii (dropdowns, notifications, quick pick, etc.), creating a visual mismatch with the OS.

## Request
- Increase VS Code’s UI corner radii on macOS 26 to align with system roundness, or  
- Expose radius design tokens (e.g., `--vscode-radius-{sm,md,lg}`) / a user setting (e.g., `"workbench.uiCornerRadius": "system" | "compact" | number`) and default to **system** on macOS 26.

## Why this matters
- Platform consistency with Tahoe’s more rounded geometry.
- Visual polish; current corners look out of place next to native windows/controls.
- Cosmetic, platform-scoped change with low risk.

## Scope / examples (non-exhaustive)
- Workbench containers: panel/sidebar headers, notifications, quick input.
- Controls: dropdowns, inputs, badges, pill chips.
- Surfaces: context menus, command palette.

## Potential drawback
Increasing corner radius can slightly reduce usable horizontal space on elements like the **status bar**, potentially squeezing text and icons and shortening visible segment lengths.

## Possible approaches
- Platform check for macOS 26 → apply a larger radius scale factor to existing tokens.
- Introduce a system-aware token that maps to larger radii on Tahoe; keep current values elsewhere.
- Allow themes to opt into “system” radii without hard-coded px values.

*(Optional mitigations for the drawback: allow “compact” radius mode, adjust status bar item spacing/overflow, enable smarter truncation or multi-row wrap when space is constrained.)*

## Additional notes
- No change requested for Windows/Linux or older macOS; only adopt Tahoe’s roundness by default (or via a “system” option).
- If an existing token/setting already tracks system corner radii, please point me to it.

title: Turn off local indexing of files in the workspace (for working with large size repo under GVFS)

labels.name: chat-codebase
labels.description: Chat codebase knowledge. Includes #codebase and @workspace

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.104.0
- OS Version: Windows 11 Enterpise 24H2 26100 

Is there a way to turn-off local indexing of files under the workspace?

We work with OS repo where files are under GVFS.   VS Code local indexing causes all the OS files under the workspace to be hydrated, leading to poor performance on git operations.  Our use case is to be able to operate under the OS repo, regardless of the # of files/folders being opened without any need to consciously thinking about the limit constraint, in order to work effectively with GHCP + a capable search tool like haystack search tool, which is going to have a capability not to trigger file hydration.

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  With gvfs mounted, open the OS repo root, or even just one or two depot.  
2.  Run "gvfs health" cmd periodically, and it will show all the files will be eventually getting hydrated.

* bump playwright mcp
